item.title: Albert Cardona
item.description: @BorisBarbour Having approached, in the recent past, vicechancellors about these issues, their answers below:There is a new scheme to provide startup packages. The heads of department don‚Äôt know about it, yet the department has to apply on behalf of the new already hired faculty‚Äînot a recruitment incentive then‚Äîand success rate is undisclosed (i.e., abysmal).Salary is OK, they say, clearly brilliant scientists keep applying (they are blind to the many that, discouraged by the salary on offer, don‚Äôt bother applying, and almost all new faculty is local).The university provides subsidised child care (at ~80% the market rate and I hope you don‚Äôt mind adding 30 min each way to your cycling commute; also, please enter the waiting list and await for over a year to be offered a half day a week ‚Äúto start‚Äù.)The vicechancellor in question lives 1 hour away by car and thinks that‚Äôs a perfectly acceptable situation. Never mind the time and gas, insurance, maintenance and parking costs to further strain the meagre salary.The NHS is a one-off cost, considered not a problem (do you know of any postdocts with about ¬£7,000 of savings ready to be committed to this?)Research funding is adequate, the UK is a world powerhouse‚Äîeven my colleagues in the humanities whose grants are tiny don‚Äôt think so.Delusion is powerful. Don‚Äôt know what will bring about change, but the present management‚Äîat the university, the research councils / UKRI, and the government‚Äîdon‚Äôt even acknowledge there is a severe, generation-defining problem.#UK #academia

item.title: Richard Ashwell
item.description: Facing prison for holding a placardRetired social worker Trudi Warner, who faces a possible two years in prison, is asking the Solicitor General to stop proceedings against her for contempt of court. Her alleged crime? Holding a placard.In March, Warner was standing outside a court in London, where climate protesters were on trial, and held up a sign reading: ‚ÄúJurors: you have an absolute right to acquit a defendant according to your conscience.‚ÄùThis legal right was established in 1670, after a judge imprisoned a jury for reaching a verdict he would not accept. The incident gave rise to a new ruling that juries have the freedom to reach decisions independently. Yet holding this sign was enough to put Warner in front of a judge at the Old Bailey ‚Äì a building with a plaque at the entrance that declares the same legal right.#RightToProtest #Protest #Protests #Authoritarianism https://goodlawproject.org/trudi-warner-climate-jury-facing-prison/
